        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>
      
      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 5:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

            <chops-button class="de-emphasized">

            </chops-button>
            
      
        <slot></slot>

              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

    <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

        Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Probably fixable by either of:<span class="line"><!---->Probably fixable by either of:<!----></span><br>1 - binding a ScopedExtensionUpdaterKeepAlive into the StartUpdateCheck callback in extension_updater.cc.<span class="line"><!---->1 - binding a ScopedExtensionUpdaterKeepAlive into the StartUpdateCheck callback in extension_updater.cc.<!----></span><br>2 - attempting cancellation of the update_service state machine in Shutdown<span class="line"><!---->2 - attempting cancellation of the update_service state machine in Shutdown<!----></span><br><br>But overall I think the memory management in the extension updater needs a closer look, there may be similar UAFs related to callbacks from the update service.<span class="line"><!---->But overall I think the memory management in the extension updater needs a closer look, there may be similar UAFs related to callbacks from the update service.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1303202#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>

      <div class="issue-diff">

          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>

        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">

          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;

          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>


      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 5:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/99.0.4844.51 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>1.- in the function PersistedData::SetDateLastData<span class="line"><!---->1.- in the function PersistedData::SetDateLastData<!----></span><br><br>- ```c++<span class="line"><!---->- ```c++<!----></span><br>  void PersistedData::SetDateLastData(const std::vector<std::string>& ids,<span class="line"><!---->  void PersistedData::SetDateLastData(const std::vector&lt;std::string&gt;&amp; ids,<!----></span><br>                                      int datenum,<span class="line"><!---->                                      int datenum,<!----></span><br>                                      base::OnceClosure callback) {<span class="line"><!---->                                      base::OnceClosure callback) {<!----></span><br>    DCHECK_CALLED_ON_VALID_SEQUENCE(sequence_checker_);<span class="line"><!---->    DCHECK_CALLED_ON_VALID_SEQUENCE(sequence_checker_);<!----></span><br>    if (!pref_service_ || datenum < 0) {<span class="line"><!---->    if (!pref_service_ || datenum &lt; 0) {<!----></span><br>      base::SequencedTaskRunnerHandle::Get()->PostTask(FROM_HERE,<span class="line"><!---->      base::SequencedTaskRunnerHandle::Get()-&gt;PostTask(FROM_HERE,<!----></span><br>                                                       std::move(callback));<span class="line"><!---->                                                       std::move(callback));<!----></span><br>      return;<span class="line"><!---->      return;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    if (!activity_data_service_) {<span class="line"><!---->    if (!activity_data_service_) {<!----></span><br>      SetDateLastDataHelper(ids, datenum, std::move(callback), {});<span class="line"><!---->      SetDateLastDataHelper(ids, datenum, std::move(callback), {});<!----></span><br>      return;<span class="line"><!---->      return;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    activity_data_service_->GetAndClearActiveBits(<span class="line"><!---->    activity_data_service_-&gt;GetAndClearActiveBits(<!----></span><br>        ids, base::BindOnce(&PersistedData::SetDateLastDataHelper, <span class="line"><!---->        ids, base::BindOnce(&amp;PersistedData::SetDateLastDataHelper, <!----></span><br>                            base::Unretained(this), ids, datenum, //here use base::Unretained(this)<span class="line"><!---->                            base::Unretained(this), ids, datenum, //here use base::Unretained(this)<!----></span><br>                            std::move(callback)));<span class="line"><!---->                            std::move(callback)));<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  ```<span class="line"><!---->  ```<!----></span><br><br>- activity_data_service_->GetAndClearActiveBits maybe enter into -->>> function  ExtensionActivityDataService::GetAndClearActiveBits()<span class="line"><!---->- activity_data_service_-&gt;GetAndClearActiveBits maybe enter into --&gt;&gt;&gt; function  ExtensionActivityDataService::GetAndClearActiveBits()<!----></span><br><br>- ```<span class="line"><!---->- ```<!----></span><br>  void ExtensionActivityDataService::GetAndClearActiveBits(<span class="line"><!---->  void ExtensionActivityDataService::GetAndClearActiveBits(<!----></span><br>      const std::vector<std::string>& ids,<span class="line"><!---->      const std::vector&lt;std::string&gt;&amp;         Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1303202#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 5:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->

        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. ids,<!----></span><br>      base::OnceCallback<void(const std::set<std::string>&)> callback) {<span class="line"><!---->      base::OnceCallback&lt;void(const std::set&lt;std::string&gt;&amp;)&gt; callback) {<!----></span><br>    std::set<std::string> actives;<span class="line"><!---->    std::set&lt;std::string&gt; actives;<!----></span><br>    for (const auto& id : ids) {<span class="line"><!---->    for (const auto&amp; id : ids) {<!----></span><br>      if (extension_prefs_->GetActiveBit(id))<span class="line"><!---->      if (extension_prefs_-&gt;GetActiveBit(id))<!----></span><br>        actives.insert(id);<span class="line"><!---->        actives.insert(id);<!----></span><br>      extension_prefs_->SetActiveBit(id, false);<span class="line"><!---->      extension_prefs_-&gt;SetActiveBit(id, false);<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    base::SequencedTaskRunnerHandle::Get()->PostTask(<span class="line"><!---->    base::SequencedTaskRunnerHandle::Get()-&gt;PostTask(<!----></span><br>        FROM_HERE, base::BindOnce(std::move(callback), actives)); // call async vallback<span class="line"><!---->        FROM_HERE, base::BindOnce(std::move(callback), actives)); // call async vallback<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>  ```<span class="line"><!---->  ```<!----></span><br>2.in real chrome how to trigger?<span class="line"><!---->2.in real chrome how to trigger?<!----></span><br>  - open two profile,  <span class="line"><!---->  - open two profile,  <!----></span><br>  - then we click update all extension<span class="line"><!---->  - then we click update all extension<!----></span><br>  - trigger extension update then enter the codepath  in one profile(maybe lots of malicious extension update?)<span class="line"><!---->  - trigger extension update then enter the codepath  in one profile(maybe lots of malicious extension update?)<!----></span><br>  - close that profile chrome to trigger uaf<span class="line"><!---->  - close that profile chrome to trigger uaf<!----></span><br>3.<span class="line"><!---->3.<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>above all<span class="line"><!---->above all<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 99.0.4844.51  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 99.0.4844.51  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: 10.0<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: 10.0<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1303202#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 5:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

          Internals&gt;Installer&gt;Components
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Probably introduced by <span class="line"><!---->Probably introduced by <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2569779<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<span class="line"><!---->The UaF is accessing the raw_ptr pref_service_ field of PersistedData, since PersistedData is destroyed.<!----></span><br><br>Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<span class="line"><!---->Medium despite browser UaF, because I don't think there's any reliable way for an attacker to abuse this given the dependency on destroying a profile.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1303202#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 8, 2022, 5:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        from the asan output, the  pref_service_ is not owned by  class PersistedData<span class="line"><!---->from the asan output, the  pref_service_ is not owned by  class PersistedData<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          Started
          (was: Assigned)

      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>

          (was: Assigned)

        I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<span class="line"><!---->I looked at this more deeply today. Thank you for the report.<!----></span><br><br>I think I want to do two things here:<span class="line"><!---->I think I want to do two things here:<!----></span><br>1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<span class="line"><!---->1 - Keep the profile alive while the extension update check is in progress. This seems necessary because the extension updater passes update_client a callback with a base::Unretained ref to itself, so it must survive the entire operation. One alternative would be to refcount or weakptr the class, but if the profile is destroyed I'm not sure how to reason about whether the PrefService pointer is still valid. (Or if there are other dependencies tracked by raw pointers, how to deal with those.) Therefore, it seems best to keep the entire profile alive until we're certain this operation is complete.<!----></span><br>2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<span class="line"><!---->2 - Remove some of the base::Unretained usage in update_client. Many occurrences are relatively straightforward to remove (refcounting or weakptrs can be used instead) and it has always been tough to reason about the memory safety of the Unretained in the case of concurrent destruction of the updater.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        While adding a keepalive to cover the update operation, I noticed that there is already a profile keep alive that is in scope while this code is running;<span class="line"><!---->While adding believe the example in <span class="line"><!---->I believe the example in <!----></span>comment #2<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c2"><!---->comment #2<!----></a> only generates a UAF because the patch adds usage of PersistedData that is outside the scope of a ScopedProfileKeepAlive. As far as I can tell, there is no UAF in unmodified Chrome. (Please correct me if I'm missing something.)<span class="line"><!----> only generates a UAF because the patch adds usage of PersistedData that is outside the scope of a ScopedProfileKeepAlive. As far as I can tell, there is no UAF in unmodified Chrome.               <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;

          padding: 0;

          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

          

          <div class="edit-actions">
            <chops-button class="de-emphasized">
              Cancel
            </chops-button>
            <chops-button class="emphasized">
               issue
            </chops-button>
          </div>
        </div>

      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);

        for LitElement.

window.prpcClient = new AutoRefreshPrpcClient(
 CS_env.token, CS_env.tokenExpiresSec);

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
